title: GD2Viz app - Explore public datasets and analyze your data
text: GD2Viz specialized visualization analysis tool designed explore tumor-specific expression GD2 — disialoganglioside growing importance cancer immunotherapy. GD2 emerged clinically actionable biomarker, due restricted expression normal tissues elevated presence malignancies neuroblastoma. Accurately assessing GD2 expression across tumor entities pivotal identifying patients may benefit targeted therapies, particularly anti-GD2 immunotherapeutics. Building methodology proposed Ustjanzew et al. (2024), GD2Viz integrates transcriptomic data curated model glycosphingolipid metabolism compute interpret GD2 Scores. scores reflect net activity pathway-level reactions called Reaction Activity Score (RAS) classified GD2-promoting GD2-mitigating. framework implemented R package interactive Shiny application, empowering users explore precomputed scores large-scale public datasets analyze custom RNA-Seq data. vignette focuses Shiny application component GD2Viz, detailing core features guiding users analytical capabilities. GD2Viz provides powerful lens examining glycosphingolipid metabolism relates GD2, users advised interpret GD2 Scores within context computational origin. scores inferential nature complement, replace, direct experimental validation. Nevertheless, GD2Viz offers scalable, transparent, biologically grounded platform advance understanding clinical utility GD2 expression profiles cancer research.

title: GD2Viz app - Explore public datasets and analyze your data
text: GD2Viz stand-alone R package, user can start use application locally. However, local version GD2Viz include exploration public RNA-seq datasets allows load data tocompute sphingolipid-pathway RAS scoresand predict GD2 score samples. Please use online version http://shiny.imbei.uni-mainz.de:3838/GD2Viz access extended version explore GD2 scores available public datasets. local installation latest version R RStudio required. package can installed remotes library: using GD2Viz research, please cite: Ustjanzew et al. Predicting GD2 expression across cancer types integration pathway topology transcriptome data. 2025

title: GD2Viz app - Explore public datasets and analyze your data
text: Public Datasets tab provides interactive interface explore GD2 Scores across six major RNA-Seq datasets: TCGA Tumor TCGA Normal GTEx TARGET St. Jude Cloud CBTTC (Pediatric Brain Tumor Atlas) RAS matrices precomputed used train Support Vector Model (SVM) linear kernel fly. ensure rapid reproducible analysis, adjusted unadjusted Reaction Activity Scores (RAS) precomputed public datasets. Additionally, RAS matrices training dataset serve input Support Vector Machine (SVM) linear kernel, trained --fly using specified preprocessing adjustment settings. trained model used predict GD2 Scores across selected dataset. Users can control two key preprocessing settings:

title: GD2Viz app - Explore public datasets and analyze your data
text: Determines RAS values prepared used model training: Raw: Uses unmodified RAS values computed gene expression. Ranged: Normalizes reaction’s activity score [0, 1] range across samples. Scaled: Standardizes RAS values zero mean unit variance (z-score transformation).

title: GD2Viz app - Explore public datasets and analyze your data
text: Specifies RAS values adjusted reflect network topology biological dependencies: Unadjusted RAS: Uses direct output RAS calculation, based purely transcriptomic input. Adjusted Transition Probability: Weighs RAS values according pathway transition probabilities, incorporating pathway structure. Recursive Adjustment: refines RAS values iterative propagation along reaction network, capturing upstream downstream pathway effects. user-defined parameters directly influence training data interpreted SVM model therefore affect resulting GD2 Score predictions. design allows users explore different biological assumptions preprocessing choices impact characterization GD2 expression across diverse RNA-Seq datasets.

title: GD2Viz app - Explore public datasets and analyze your data
text: GD2 Score can visualized using three plot types: Scatter plot: Ideal viewing individual sample distributions Box plot: Useful summarizing group-level differences Violin plot: Highlights summary statistics distribution density Users can also normalize GD2 Scores [0–1] range cross-dataset comparison.

title: GD2Viz app - Explore public datasets and analyze your data
text: Samples can grouped metadata variables (e.g., Primary_Disease) contextualize GD2 Score distributions across conditions. Additionally, users may highlight specific groups — example, highlighting Glioblastoma Multiforme within TCGA dataset. tab ideal hypothesis generation, comparative analysis cancer types elevated GD2 expression may candidates targeted anti-GD2 therapy.

title: GD2Viz app - Explore public datasets and analyze your data
text: zero value GD2 Score represents SVM hyper plane dividing GD2-high samples GD2-low samples. GD2 Score sample equal SVM decision weight sample. means, samples GD2 Score far zero GD2 negative, samples close zero unclear/intermediate GD2 expression samples far zero might express high levels GD2.

title: GD2Viz app - Explore public datasets and analyze your data
text: TCGA Cancer Types tab enables detailed exploration individual tumor types within TCGA dataset. Users can select specific TCGA project (e.g., Glioblastoma Multiforme) visualize GD2 Scores across clinically molecularly defined subgroups, mRNA subtypes, DNA methylation classes, available metadata variables. Public Datasets tab, users can configure key model parameters influence GD2 Score prediction: RAS processing method: raw, ranged, scaled RAS adjustment type: unadjusted, adjusted transition probability, recursively adjusted resulting plot displays GD2 Scores grouped selected stratification variable, providing insight intratumoral heterogeneity subtype-specific GD2 expression.

title: GD2Viz app - Explore public datasets and analyze your data
text: Beyond visualization, tab includes powerful Differential Expression Analysis module investigate transcriptomic differences GD2-defined sample groups. Users can stratify samples based GD2 Scores using: median split (GD2-high vs. GD2-low) custom threshold value Upper- vs. lower GD2 Score percentiles Additionally, user can select DESeq2 limma-voom pipelines compute DEA. want analyze 20 samples, suggest limma-voom computation faster.

title: GD2Viz app - Explore public datasets and analyze your data
text: DEA results section offers multi-faceted view differential gene regulation: Summary statistics: Total number upregulated downregulated genes Searchable results table: View, filter, sort significant genes Gene-specific details: Select gene table see additional annotation visualize expression distribution across GD2-defined groups Interactive volcano plot: Visualize effect size significance MA plot: Assess expression fold changes versus mean expression P-value Histogram: Assesses distribution raw p-values evaluate test validity potential signal Log2 Fold-Change Histogram: Provides global overview magnitude directionality differential gene expression integrated analysis allows users link GD2 Score variation broader transcriptomic changes, helping generate hypotheses GD2-associated pathways, biomarkers, therapeutic targets within specific cancer types. results DEA can downloaded.

previous_headings: Tab ‘Analyze Your Data’ (local and online versions)
title: GD2Viz app - Explore public datasets and analyze your data
text: Users can upload data one two formats: Count matrix metadata (.tsv format): count matrix contain raw, unnormalized counts, rows labeled Gene Symbols columns representing samples. metadata file contain sample-level annotations. Column names count matrix must match row names metadata file. DESeqDataSet object (.rds format): serialized R object containing counts metadata, typically generated DESeq2 pipeline. Text file count data:  Text file metadata (exerimental variables):  ⚠️ Make sure input files properly formatted - sample names order. metadata file can include experimental variables subtype, treatment, batch later grouping analysis.

what: Vignette: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz
title: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz
text: vignette demonstrates use GD2Viz R package compute Reaction Activity Scores predict GD2 Scores GSE147635 dataset, includes neuroblastoma (NB) ganglioneuroma (GN) samples. workflow uses pre-trained models pathway graphs GD2Viz package walks process step step using base R Bioconductor conventions.

previous_headings: Vignette: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz
title: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz
code: library(DESeq2) library(SummarizedExperiment) library(GD2Viz) library(AnnotationDbi) library(org.Hs.eg.db) library(kernlab)

previous_headings: Vignette: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz
what: 2. Load Training Data and Metabolic Graph
title: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz
text: precomputed resources required GD2Viz RAS computation model training.
code: train.data <- readRDS(system.file("extdata", "train_data.Rds", package = "GD2Viz")) mgraph <- readRDS(system.file("extdata", "substrate_graph.Rds", package = "GD2Viz"))

previous_headings: Vignette: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz > 3. Load and Prepare the GSE147635 Dataset
title: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz
text: setup count files (.tsv) per sample located data/GSE147635-counts
code: counts_dir <- "./data/GSE147635-counts" count_files <- list.files(counts_dir)  file_path <- file.path(counts_dir, count_files[1]) df <- read.table(file_path, header = FALSE, sep = "\t") names(df) <- c("rowname", count_files[1])  for (file in count_files[-1]) {   file_path <- file.path(counts_dir, file)   temp_df <- read.table(file_path, header = FALSE, sep = "\t")   names(temp_df) <- c("rowname", file)   df <- cbind(df, temp_df[, file, drop = FALSE]) }

previous_headings: Vignette: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz > 3. Load and Prepare the GSE147635 Dataset
what: 3.2 Construct Count Matrix, Metadata, and Annotation
title: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz
code: rownames(df) <- df$rowname df <- df[, -1] colnames(df) <- gsub("_count.tsv", "", colnames(df))  # Remove cell line samples NB_CL <- c("SRR11434496", "SRR11434497", "SRR11434498") df <- df[, !colnames(df) %in% NB_CL]  # Metadata coldata_NB_GN <- data.frame(type = c(rep("GN", 6), rep("NB", 15))) rownames(coldata_NB_GN) <- colnames(df)  # Annotation using ENSEMBL -> SYMBOL and ENTREZ ensemblIDs <- gsub("\\..*", "", rownames(df)) geneSymbol <- AnnotationDbi::mapIds(org.Hs.eg.db, keys = ensemblIDs, keytype = "ENSEMBL", column = "SYMBOL") entrezIDs <- AnnotationDbi::mapIds(org.Hs.eg.db, keys = ensemblIDs, keytype = "ENSEMBL", column = "ENTREZID") rowdata <- data.frame(ensemblIDs = ensemblIDs, geneSymbol = geneSymbol, entrezIDs = entrezIDs, row.names = rownames(df))

previous_headings: Vignette: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz > 3. Load and Prepare the GSE147635 Dataset
title: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz
code: NB_GN_dds <- DESeqDataSetFromMatrix(df, coldata_NB_GN, design = ~type) rowData(NB_GN_dds) <- rowdata  # Keep only genes with valid symbols and remove duplicates NB_GN_dds <- NB_GN_dds[!is.na(rowData(NB_GN_dds)$geneSymbol), ] NB_GN_dds <- NB_GN_dds[!duplicated(rowData(NB_GN_dds)$geneSymbol), ] rownames(NB_GN_dds) <- rowData(NB_GN_dds)$geneSymbol # inspect dds object > NB_GN_dds class: DESeqDataSet  dim: 60603 21  metadata(1): version assays(1): counts rownames(60603): ENSG00000000003.14 ENSG00000000005.6 ... ENSG00000288110.1 ENSG00000288111.1 rowData names(3): ensemblIDs geneSymbol entrezIDs colnames(21): SRR11434490 SRR11434491 ... SRR11434512 SRR11434513 colData names(1): type

previous_headings: Vignette: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz
title: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz
text: computes unadjusted adjusted RAS matrices (ras, ras_prob, ras_prob_rec) using glycosphingolipid pathway structure.
code: res <- computeReactionActivityScores(dds = NB_GN_dds, mgraph = mgraph, geom = metadata(train.data)$geom)

previous_headings: Vignette: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz
title: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz
text: model corresponds different RAS adjustment strategy, trained raw input.
code: kernfit.ras <- trainGD2model(train.data, adjust_ras = "ras", adjust_input = "raw", type_column = "X_study") kernfit.ras_prob <- trainGD2model(train.data, adjust_ras = "ras_prob", adjust_input = "raw", type_column = "X_study") kernfit.ras_prob_rec <- trainGD2model(train.data, adjust_ras = "ras_prob_rec", adjust_input = "raw", type_column = "X_study") # inspect object > kernfit.ras Support Vector Machine object of class "ksvm"   SV type: C-svc  (classification)   parameter : cost C = 1   Linear (vanilla) kernel function.   Number of Support Vectors : 159   Objective Function Value : -142.1803  Training error : 0.006227

previous_headings: Vignette: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz
title: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz
text: GD2res object contains predicted GD2 scores dataset based corresponding RAS matrix. GD2res.ras$preds contains predicted GD2 score per sample. GD2res.ras$input_df contains sum RAS GD2 promoting (x) GD2 mitigating (y) reactions.

previous_headings: Vignette: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz > 7. Visualize GD2 Scores
title: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz
text: plot helps distinguish GD2-high GD2-low phenotypes NB GN groups, can inform potential downstream DEA biomarker analysis.
code: df_plot <- data.frame(   sample = names(GD2res.ras_prob$preds),   GD2_score = GD2res.ras_prob$preds,   group = colData(NB_GN_dds)$type )  ggplot2::ggplot(df_plot, ggplot2::aes(x = group, y = GD2_score, fill = group)) +   ggplot2::geom_boxplot() +   ggplot2::geom_jitter(width = 0.2, size = 2, alpha = 0.6) +   ggplot2::labs(     title = "Predicted GD2 Score",     x = "Sample Group",     y = "GD2 Score"   ) +   ggplot2::theme_minimal()

previous_headings: Vignette: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz
title: Computing GD2 Scores Programmatically Using GD2Viz

what: Explore GD2 scores of large datasets. Compute and visualize GD2 score of your RNA-seq datasets
title: Explore GD2 scores of large datasets. Compute and visualize GD2 score of your RNA-seq datasets
text: Welcome GD2Viz, powerful user-friendly visualization tool designed help researchers clinicians explore, analyze, interpret GD2 Scores across various RNA-Seq datasets. Utilizing advanced methodology outlined Ustjanzew et al. (2024), GD2Viz offers -depth examination precomputed GD2 Scores publicly available RNA-Seq datasets TCGA, GTEx, TARGET. Users also flexibility upload analyze datasets within context GD2 Scores. GD2Viz provides range interactive visualizations precomputed RNA-seq datasets. Additionally, GD2Viz R package includes several functions computing Reaction Activity Scores glycosphingolipid metabolism predicting GD2 Scores directly within R environment. comprehensive guidance, refer articles GD2Viz webpage. ⚠️ Note: local version include access precomputed public datasets (e.g., TCGA, GTEx, TARGET). explore GD2 Scores across datasets, please use online version app, available : http://shiny.imbei.uni-mainz.de:3838/GD2Viz

title: Explore GD2 scores of large datasets. Compute and visualize GD2 score of your RNA-seq datasets
text: GD2Viz provides comprehensive framework analysis, visualization, interpretation GD2 expression potential across bulk RNA-Seq datasets, focus glycosphingolipid metabolism. package includes interactive Shiny application set R functions programmatic use.

title: Explore GD2 scores of large datasets. Compute and visualize GD2 score of your RNA-seq datasets
text: Implements trained Support Vector Machine (SVM) model infer GD2 Scores transcriptomic data. Integrates pathway informed features glycosphingolipid metabolism via Reaction Activity Scores (RAS).

title: Explore GD2 scores of large datasets. Compute and visualize GD2 score of your RNA-seq datasets
text: Interactive Shiny App: Explore GD2 Scores across large public datasets online (TCGA, GTEx, TARGET, St. Jude Cloud, CBTTC). Visualize GD2 Scores using scatter, box, violin plots grouped clinical molecular subtypes. Heatmaps, scatter plots, pathway diagrams interpret RAS distributions.

text: Perform GD2-based sample stratification (e.g., high vs. low) run DEA directly app programmatically. Visualize DEA results volcano plots, MA plots, p-value log2 fold-change histograms. Searchable gene tables built-annotation gene-specific expression profiles.

what: Assign Sample Expression Values to Graph Edges — assignSampleExpression
title: Assign Sample Expression Values to Graph Edges — assignSampleExpression
text: assignSampleExpression function calculates assigns sample expression values edges input graph using specified sample expression data. function augments input graph additional edge attributes representing aggregated sample expression values based gene information associated edges.

title: Assign Sample Expression Values to Graph Edges — assignSampleExpression
code: assignSampleExpression(   igraph,   sample_expr,   gene_column = "symbol",   attr_name = "edge_sum",   output_graph = FALSE )

title: Assign Sample Expression Values to Graph Edges — assignSampleExpression
text: igraph igraph object representing graph sample expression data assigned. sample_expr named numeric vector containing sample expression values individual genes. names vector correspond gene identifiers used gene_column. gene_column character string specifying name edge attribute graph contains gene identifiers. Defaults "symbol". attr_name character string specifying name edge attribute aggregated sample expression values assigned. Defaults "edge_sum". output_graph logical value indicating whether function return graph assigned edge attributes (TRUE) just vector aggregated expression values (FALSE). Defaults FALSE.

title: Assign Sample Expression Values to Graph Edges — assignSampleExpression
text: output_graph TRUE, returns modified igraph object edge attributes assigned. output_graph FALSE, returns numeric vector containing aggregated sample expression values edge.

title: Assign Sample Expression Values to Graph Edges — assignSampleExpression
text: function assumes input graph edge attributes containing gene identifiers (default column name: "symbol"), sample_expr vector contains numeric expression values genes. function uses igraph package working graphs edge attributes.

title: Assign Sample Expression Values to Graph Edges — assignSampleExpression
code: # Create a sample igraph object library(igraph) g <- make_ring(10) E(g)$symbol <- sample(letters, 10, replace = TRUE)  # Create a sample expression vector sample_expr <- setNames(runif(26), letters)  # Assign sample expression values to graph edges g_with_expr <- assignSampleExpression(g, sample_expr, output_graph = TRUE)  # Get the aggregated sample expression values as a vector edge_expr_vec <- assignSampleExpression(g, sample_expr, output_graph = FALSE)

what: Assign Transition Probabilities to Graph Edges — assignTP
title: Assign Transition Probabilities to Graph Edges — assignTP
text: assignTP function assigns transition probabilities edges input graph based specified transition probability data. function enhances graph's edges additional attributes representing transition probabilities associated specific reactions entities. used within context computeTransitionProbability function.

title: Assign Transition Probabilities to Graph Edges — assignTP
code: assignTP(   igraph,   transition_probability,   column = "miriam.kegg.reaction",   attr_name = "tp" )

title: Assign Transition Probabilities to Graph Edges — assignTP
text: igraph igraph object representing graph transition probabilities assigned. transition_probability named numeric vector containing transition probabilities individual reactions entities. names vector correspond identifiers used specified column. column character string specifying name edge attribute graph contains identifiers reactions entities. Defaults "miriam.kegg.reaction". attr_name character string specifying name edge attribute transition probabilities assigned. Defaults "tp".

title: Assign Transition Probabilities to Graph Edges — assignTP
text: input igraph object transition probabilities assigned edge attributes.

title: Assign Transition Probabilities to Graph Edges — assignTP
text: function assumes input graph edge attributes containing identifiers reactions entities (default column name: "miriam.kegg.reaction"), transition_probability vector contains numeric transition probability values identifiers.

title: Assign Transition Probabilities to Graph Edges — assignTP
code: # Create a sample igraph object library(igraph) g <- make_ring(10) E(g)$`miriam.kegg.reaction` <- sample(letters[1:5], 10, replace = TRUE)  # Create a sample transition probability vector tp <- setNames(runif(5), letters[1:5])  # Assign transition probabilities to graph edges g_with_tp <- assignTP(g, tp)

title: Compute GD2 Score — computeGD2Score
text: computeGD2Score function calculates GD2 score using given reaction activity score (RAS) matrix SVM model. allows various adjustments input data scoring.

title: Compute GD2 Score — computeGD2Score
code: computeGD2Score(   RAS,   svm_model,   adjust_input = c("raw", "ranged", "scaled"),   range_output = FALSE,   center = TRUE )

title: Compute GD2 Score — computeGD2Score
text: RAS matrix reaction activity scores reaction IDs row names samples columns. svm_model SVM model used predicting GD2 score. adjust_input character string indicating adjust input data. Options "raw" (adjustment), "ranged" (rescale [0, 1]), "scaled" (standardize mean 0 standard deviation 1). Default "raw". range_output logical value indicating whether rescale output data. Default FALSE. center logical value indicating whether center data scaling. Default TRUE.

title: Compute GD2 Score — computeGD2Score
text: numeric vector GD2 scores samples.

title: Compute GD2 Score — computeGD2Score
code: # Example RAS matrix with necessary reaction IDs RAS <- matrix(runif(6 * 10), nrow = 6,   dimnames = list(c("R05946", "R05940", "R05939", "R05948", "R05947", "R05941")))  # Example SVM model svm_model <- e1071::svm(x = data.frame(x = rnorm(10), y = rnorm(10)),   y = rnorm(10),   type = "eps-regression")  # Compute GD2 scores with raw input scores <- computeGD2Score(RAS, svm_model, adjust_input = "raw")

what: Compute Reaction Activity Values for Graph Edges — computeReactionActivity
title: Compute Reaction Activity Values for Graph Edges — computeReactionActivity
text: computeReactionActivity function computes assigns reaction activity values edges input graph based provided gene expression counts data. function facilitates computation reaction activities incorporates values edge attributes within graph.

title: Compute Reaction Activity Values for Graph Edges — computeReactionActivity
code: computeReactionActivity(   igraph,   counts,   gene_column = "symbol",   attr_name = "edge_sum",   output_graph = FALSE,   rowname_column = "miriam.kegg.reaction" )

title: Compute Reaction Activity Values for Graph Edges — computeReactionActivity
text: igraph igraph object representing graph reaction activity values assigned. counts numeric matrix data frame containing gene expression counts data. column represents sample, row corresponds gene. gene_column character string specifying name edge attribute graph contains gene identifiers. Defaults "symbol". attr_name character string specifying name edge attribute computed reaction activity values assigned. Defaults "edge_sum". output_graph logical value indicating whether function return modified graph assigned edge attributes (TRUE) data frame computed reaction activities (FALSE). Defaults FALSE. rowname_column TODOTODO

title: Compute Reaction Activity Values for Graph Edges — computeReactionActivity
text: output_graph TRUE, returns list modified igraph objects assigned reaction activity edge attributes sample. output_graph FALSE, returns data frame containing computed reaction activity values sample reaction.

title: Compute Reaction Activity Values for Graph Edges — computeReactionActivity
text: function assumes input graph edge attributes containing gene identifiers (default column name: "symbol"), counts matrix data frame contains numeric expression counts genes. function uses igraph package working graphs edge attributes.

title: Compute Reaction Activity Values for Graph Edges — computeReactionActivity
code: # Create a sample igraph object library(igraph) g <- make_ring(10) E(g)$symbol <- sample(letters, 10, replace = TRUE)  # Create a sample counts matrix counts <- matrix(runif(260), nrow = 26, dimnames = list(letters, paste0("Sample", 1:10)))  # Compute reaction activity values and modify the graph g_with_activity <- computeReactionActivity(g, counts, output_graph = TRUE)  # Compute reaction activity values and get as a data frame reaction_activity_df <- computeReactionActivity(g, counts, output_graph = FALSE)

what: Compute Reaction Activity Scores for Custom Dataset — computeReactionActivityScores
title: Compute Reaction Activity Scores for Custom Dataset — computeReactionActivityScores
text: computeReactionActivityScores function computes reaction activity scores custom dataset using provided metabolic network, training data geometric means, parameters. integrates gene expression data metabolic network derive reaction activity scores, transition probabilities, adjusted reaction activity matrices.

title: Compute Reaction Activity Scores for Custom Dataset — computeReactionActivityScores
code: computeReactionActivityScores(   counts = NULL,   metadata = NULL,   dds = NULL,   mgraph,   geom )

title: Compute Reaction Activity Scores for Custom Dataset — computeReactionActivityScores
text: counts data frame matrix containing raw unnormalized RNA-Seq gene counts. Columns samples, rows genes. metadata data frame containing sample metadata. Required counts provided. dds DESeqDataSet object. provided, counts metadata ignored. mgraph graph object representing metabolic network. geom named numeric vector containing geometric means training dataset.

title: Compute Reaction Activity Scores for Custom Dataset — computeReactionActivityScores
text: list containing various Reaction Activity scores computed custom dataset based provided metabolic network training data. custom_coldata modified sample metadata corresponding custom dataset. ras original Reaction Activity matrix computed custom dataset. ras_prob Reaction Activity matrix adjusted transition probabilities. ras_prob_path Reaction Activity matrix adjusted transition probabilities considering target node. ras_prob_rec Reaction Activity matrix adjusted transition probabilities recursive adjustment method. ras_prob_up Reaction Activity matrix adjusted adding transition probabilities. ras_prob_up_path Reaction Activity matrix adjusted adding transition probabilities considering target node. ras_prob_up_rec Reaction Activity matrix adjusted adding transition probabilities recursive adjustment method.

title: Compute Reaction Activity Scores for Custom Dataset — computeReactionActivityScores
text: function integrates gene expression data metabolic network compute reaction activity scores. estimates size factors custom dataset based geometric means training dataset normalizes gene expression data accordingly. function computes Reaction Activity scores transition probabilities custom dataset using provided metabolic network. Various adjustments applied Reaction Activity scores derive different metrics, including considering transition probabilities, target nodes, recursive adjustment methods.

title: Compute Reaction Activity Scores for Custom Dataset — computeReactionActivityScores
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Load necessary data geom <- readRDS("./SVM_GD2_dashboard/data/geom_train_data.Rds") custom_counts <-   read.table("SVM_GD2_dashboard/data/datasets/custom_counts.tsv", sep = "\t", header = TRUE) custom_coldata <-   read.table("SVM_GD2_dashboard/data/datasets/custom_metadata.tsv", sep = "\t", header = TRUE) mgraph <- load_metabolic_network("path/to/metabolic_network.graphml")  # Compute Reaction Activity scores for the custom dataset reaction_activity <- computeReactionActivityScores(custom_counts, custom_coldata, mgraph, geom) } # }

what: Compute Transition Probabilities for Graph Edges — computeTransitionProbability
title: Compute Transition Probabilities for Graph Edges — computeTransitionProbability
text: computeTransitionProbability function computes transition probabilities edges list igraph objects based adjacency edge attributes. function allows computation transition probabilities offers option adjust transition probability matrices paths originating target node using recursive adjustment method.

title: Compute Transition Probabilities for Graph Edges — computeTransitionProbability
code: computeTransitionProbability(   igraph_list,   attr_name,   attr_rownames,   target_node = NULL,   pass_through = FALSE,   mgraph )

title: Compute Transition Probabilities for Graph Edges — computeTransitionProbability
text: igraph_list list igraph objects transition probabilities computed. attr_name character string specifying name edge attribute graph contains transition probabilities. attr_rownames character string specifying name edge attribute provides row names transition probability matrix. target_node optional character string specifying target node paths considered. Defaults NULL. pass_through logical value indicating whether compute transition probabilities additional step (recursive adjustment). Defaults FALSE. mgraph TODOTODO

title: Compute Transition Probabilities for Graph Edges — computeTransitionProbability
text: matrix computed transition probabilities. Rows correspond edge attributes specified attr_rownames, columns correspond igraph objects igraph_list (samples).

title: Compute Transition Probabilities for Graph Edges — computeTransitionProbability
text: function assumes input graph edge attributes containing identifiers reactions entities (default column name: "miriam.kegg.reaction"), transition_probability vector contains numeric transition probability values identifiers.

title: Compute Transition Probabilities for Graph Edges — computeTransitionProbability
code: # Create a list of sample igraph objects library(igraph) g1 <- make_ring(10) g2 <- make_ring(10) E(g1)$`miriam.kegg.reaction` <- sample(letters[1:5], 10, replace = TRUE) E(g2)$`miriam.kegg.reaction` <- sample(letters[1:5], 10, replace = TRUE) igraph_list <- list(g1, g2)  # Compute transition probabilities transition_probs <-   computeTransitionProbability(igraph_list, attr_name = "weight",                                attr_rownames = "miriam.kegg.reaction") #> Error in get.adjacency.dense(graph, type = type, attr = attr, weights = NULL,     names = names, loops = "once"): no such edge attribute

title: GD2Viz — GD2Viz-pkg
text: Welcome GD2Viz, powerful user-friendly visualization tool designed help researchers clinicians explore, analyze, interpret GD2 Scores across various RNA-Seq datasets. Utilizing advanced methodology outlined Ustjanzew et al. (2024), GD2Viz offers -depth examination precomputed GD2 Scores publicly available RNA-Seq datasets TCGA, GTEx, TARGET. Users also flexibility upload analyze datasets within context GD2 Scores. R Shiny application version GD2Viz provides range interactive visualizations preloaded datasets. Additionally, GD2Viz R package includes several functions computing Reaction Activity Scores glycosphingolipid metabolism predicting GD2 Scores directly within R environment.

title: GD2Viz — GD2Viz-pkg
text: Arsenij Ustjanzew arsenij.ustjanzew@uni-mainz.de Maintainer: Arsenij Ustjanzew arsenij.ustjanzew@uni-mainz.de

what: MA-plot from base means and log fold changes — plot_ma
title: MA-plot from base means and log fold changes — plot_ma
text: MA-plot base means log fold changes, ggplot2 framework, additional support annotate genes provided.

title: MA-plot from base means and log fold changes — plot_ma
code: plot_ma(   res_obj,   FDR = 0.05,   point_alpha = 0.2,   sig_color = "red",   annotation_obj = NULL,   draw_y0 = TRUE,   hlines = NULL,   title = NULL,   xlab = "mean of normalized counts - log10 scale",   ylim = NULL,   add_rug = TRUE,   intgenes = NULL,   intgenes_color = "steelblue",   labels_intgenes = TRUE,   labels_repel = TRUE )

title: MA-plot from base means and log fold changes — plot_ma
text: res_obj DESeq2::DESeqResults() object FDR Numeric value, significance level thresholding adjusted p-values point_alpha Alpha transparency value points (0 = transparent, 1 = opaque) sig_color Color use mark differentially expressed genes. Defaults red annotation_obj data.frame object, row.names gene identifiers (e.g. ENSEMBL ids) column, gene_name, containing e.g. HGNC-based gene symbols. Optional draw_y0 Logical, whether draw horizontal line y=0. Defaults TRUE. hlines y coordinate (absolute value) draw horizontal lines, optional title title plot, optional xlab X axis label, defaults "mean normalized counts - log10 scale" ylim Vector two numeric values, Y axis limits restrict view add_rug Logical, whether add rug plots margins intgenes Vector genes interest. Gene symbols symbol column provided res_obj, else identifiers specified row names intgenes_color color use mark genes main plot. labels_intgenes Logical, whether add gene identifiers/names close marked plots labels_repel Logical, whether use geom_text_repel placing labels features mark

title: MA-plot from base means and log fold changes — plot_ma

code: library("airway") #> Error in library("airway"): there is no package called ‘airway’ data("airway", package = "airway") #> Error in find.package(package, lib.loc, verbose = verbose): there is no package called ‘airway’ airway #> Error: object 'airway' not found dds_airway <- DESeq2::DESeqDataSetFromMatrix(assay(airway),   colData = colData(airway),   design = ~ cell + dex ) #> Error in h(simpleError(msg, call)): error in evaluating the argument 'x' in selecting a method for function 'ncol': error in evaluating the argument 'x' in selecting a method for function 'assay': object 'airway' not found # subsetting for quicker run, ignore the next two commands if regularly using the function gene_subset <- c(   "ENSG00000103196", # CRISPLD2   "ENSG00000120129", # DUSP1   "ENSG00000163884", # KLF15   "ENSG00000179094", # PER1   rownames(dds_airway)[rep(c(rep(FALSE, 99), TRUE), length.out = nrow(dds_airway))] ) # 1% of ids #> Error: object 'dds_airway' not found dds_airway <- dds_airway[gene_subset, ] #> Error: object 'dds_airway' not found  dds_airway <- DESeq2::DESeq(dds_airway) #> Error: object 'dds_airway' not found res_airway <- DESeq2::results(dds_airway) #> Error: object 'dds_airway' not found  plot_ma(res_airway, FDR = 0.05, hlines = 1) #> Error: object 'res_airway' not found  plot_ma(res_airway,   FDR = 0.1,   intgenes = c(     "ENSG00000103196", # CRISPLD2     "ENSG00000120129", # DUSP1     "ENSG00000163884", # KLF15     "ENSG00000179094"  # PER1   )  ) #> Error: object 'res_airway' not found

title: Train GD2 Model — trainGD2model
text: trainGD2model function trains GD2 model using specified reaction activity score (RAS) matrix training data stored SummarizedExperiment object.

title: Train GD2 Model — trainGD2model
code: trainGD2model(   train_data,   adjust_ras = c("ras", "ras_prob", "ras_prob_rec"),   adjust_input = c("raw", "ranged", "scaled"),   center = TRUE,   type_column = "X_study" )

title: Train GD2 Model — trainGD2model
text: train_data SummarizedExperiment object containing training data. include: assays: "ras", "ras_prob", "ras_prob_path", "ras_prob_rec". colData: Column data information. metadata(train_data)$geom: numeric vector geometric mean data genes. adjust_ras assay use. One "ras", "ras_prob", "ras_prob_path", "ras_prob_rec". adjust_input adjust input matrix: "raw", "ranged", "scaled". center Logical; whether mean-center data using "scaled" adjustment. type_column Column name colData indicating sample type.

title: Train GD2 Model — trainGD2model
text: SVM model trained using kernlab::ksvm.

title: Train GD2 Model — trainGD2model
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Train GD2 model with raw input model <- trainGD2model(train_data, adjust_ras = "ras", adjust_input = "raw") } # }
